section.title: Multiplicative Inverses

statement.p: In our algebra and calculus classes, where we worked in \Q and \R, all non-zero numbers had multiplicative inverses. For example, 5^{-1} = \frac15 since 5^{-1}\cdot 5 = 1. But \frac15 \not \in Z!

When we're working with only integers, in particular in congruence classes modulo an integer m, fractions aren't a thing. Some numbers, though, do have multiplicative inverses. They're special, and we explore them in this section.

Why do we care? At this point, the only algebraic equations we can solve are of the form x + b \equiv c\pmod{m}. The multiplicative inverses help us solve the algebraic, affine equations, ax + b \equiv c\pmod{m}.
Let a be an integer and m a positive integer. We define a multiplicative inverse of a modulo m to be an integer b such that ab \equiv 1 \pmod{m}.
Since 3 \cdot 5\equiv 1 \pmod{7}, we say that 3 is a multiplicative inverse of 5 modulo 7. Similarly, 5 is a multiplicative inverse of 3 modulo 7.

statement.p: Let's create a multiplication table modulo 9. The following Sage code does it for us. You can change the variable n to other numbers to quickly generate other multiplication tables.

The output is a table/matrix whose i, jth entry is i \cdot j \pmod{n}.
n = 9 rows = [] for i in range(1, n): rows.append(list(map((lambda x: (i*x)%n), [x for x in range(1,n)])))

section.p: Computing a multiplication table is tedious if we just want to find a multiplicative inverse to solve a linear congruence. Similarly, guess-and-check is generally inefficient. Now we turn to a powerful fact that gives rise to an algorithm to find inverses.

statement.p: If a \and m are relatively prime integers and m \gt 1, then an inverse of a modulo m exists.

ol.li: The inverse of a \text{ modulo } m is its Bezout coefficient in {\gcd(a,m) = as + mt}
The inverse is also unique (up to congruence), but we won't prove that here.

li.p: Since \gcd(6,10) =2 \ne 1, there isn't a unique solution! We can't use the Euclidean Algorithm to find our inverse and instead have to rely on trial and error.
Since 6\cdot 4 = 24 \equiv 4 \pmod{10}, we have that 4 is one solution. Similarly, you can check that 9 is also a solution.
This congruence has two solutions modulo 10, x=4 and x=9.

To have the property that every number has an inverse modulo n, the number n must be prime
